prompt: Facts: Marriage between T. Manikandan (Appellant/A1) and Revathi (deceased) solemnized on 18.02.2013.; Accused: A1 (Husband), A2 (Muniappan - Father-in-law), A3 (Lakshmi - Mother-in-law).; Allegation: Dowry demand of 5 sovereigns of gold jewellery and Rs. 50,000 cash made by accused prior to and after marriage.; Incident Date: 17.06.2013, between 8:00 AM and 11:30 AM.; Incident Location: Matrimonial home of the deceased.; Event: Revathi was found dead by hanging inside her matrimonial home.; Complaint: Filed by PW1 (father of the deceased) alleging harassment and dowry demands leading to death.; FIR: Registered under Sections 498A and 304B IPC.; Investigation: Conducted, including inquest (Ex.P14) and witness examinations.; Medical Evidence (Post-Mortem 1 - Ex.P3 by PW4): Ligature mark noted; Hyoid bone found intact.; Medical Evidence (Post-Mortem 2 - Ex.P10 by PW11, requested by PW1): Alleged fracture of hyoid bone noted, contradictions with first PM regarding ligature mark description.; Key Witnesses: PW1 (Father), PW2 (Mother), PW3 (Sister) testified about dowry demands and harassment. PW5, PW6, PW7 (neighbours/independent witnesses) turned hostile or did not support prosecution case on dowry.; Trial Court Verdict: A1 convicted under Section 304B IPC (7 years RI). A2 and A3 convicted under Section 498A IPC (3 years RI + fine).; Appeal: Filed by A1, A2, and A3 before the Madras High Court challenging the trial court's conviction. | IPC: Section 304B (Dowry Death), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 113B, Indian Evidence Act (Presumption as to dowry death)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The death of Revathi was an unnatural death (hanging) occurring within 7 years of marriage (Married Feb 2013, Died June 2013).", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207", "Shanti v. State of Haryana (1991) 1 SCC 371", "State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1"]}, {"argument": "The deceased was subjected to cruelty and harassment by A1, A2, and A3 in connection with demands for dowry (5 sovereigns gold, Rs. 50,000) soon before her death, as testified by PW1, PW2, and PW3.", "precedents": ["Pathan Hussain Basha v. State of A.P. (2012) 8 SCC 594", "Surinder Kaur v. State of Haryana (2004) 4 SCC 109", "Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177"]}, {"argument": "Once the foundational facts of Section 304B IPC are established (unnatural death within 7 years, subjected to dowry-related cruelty soon before death), the legal presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act arises against the accused (A1).", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1", "Hem Chand v. State of Haryana (1994) 6 SCC 727", "Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "Prosecution failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the death was homicidal or that any cruelty meted out was proximately linked to the death ('soon before death' requirement not met).", "precedents": ["Kaliaperumal v. State of Tamil Nadu (2004) 9 SCC 157", "Baijnath v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2017) 1 SCC 101", "Mangat Ram v. State of Haryana (2014) 12 SCC 595"]}, {"argument": "The testimonies of interested witnesses (PW1, PW2, PW3) regarding dowry demands and cruelty are unreliable, uncorroborated by independent witnesses (who turned hostile), and contain contradictions.", "precedents": ["Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129", "Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201", "Harbeer Singh v. Sheeshpal Singh (2016) 16 SCC 418"]}, {"argument": "Specific allegations against A2 and A3 (parents-in-law) for Section 498A are vague and lack particularity. General allegations are insufficient for conviction.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207", "Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667", "Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741"]}, {"argument": "Contradictions between the first post-mortem (Ex.P3 by PW4) and the second post-mortem (Ex.P10 by PW11) create substantial doubt regarding the cause of death, benefiting the accused.", "precedents": ["Mohd. Zahid v. State of T.N. (1999) 6 SCC 123", "State of A.P. v. Raj Gopal Asawa (2004) 4 SCC 470", "Selvam @ Chellapandi v. State (Madras High Court - Crl.A(MD)No.189 of 2010) - (As HC precedents often cite other HC cases)"]}]}
